clues.text: Jefferson wrote the rough draft but it's Timothy Matlack's handwriting we see on this document
At age 19, this French captain was commissioned a major general in the Continental Army by Congress
This 1765 act called for duties on dozens of items, including a fee on all notarized papers
In July 1958, at the request of President Chamoun, U.S. Marines were sent into this Mideast country
Plans for the World Bank & the IMF were drawn up in 1944 at Bretton Woods in this state
Archaeopteryx. which lived millions of years ago, had well-developed ones in its mouth
Several species of this large shaggy bird native to Australia were exterminated by settlers
Some singing canaries are bred in these mountains whose name may remind you of a brand of bird food
The rhea is native to this continent where it associates with guanacos & forms mixed herds
The oo of this U.S. state may be extinct though it's believed one was sighted in 1981
When Ginger Rogers won an Oscar before he did, he sent her a 1-word telegram: "Ouch!"
On May 18, 1990 the lights on Las Vegas' strip went dark for 10 minutes in honor of this late tap dancer
Eugene Loring choreographed the 1938 ballet about this youthful outlaw, & he starred in it, too
Judith Jamison succeeded this late Black choreographer as director of his American dance theater
Red-haired ballerina who made her film debut in "The Red Shoes" in 1948
It succeeded Spanish town as Jamaica's capital in 1872
This Arab capital was devastated by the Iraqi army during the Persian Gulf War
This 3000-year-old Afghan capital was called Kabura by Ptolemy
This capital is located on a high plain sometimes called the Valley of Nepal
This Sudanese capital's name is Arabic for "elephant's trunk" due to its site on a narrow peninsula
This star of "Little Caesar" wasn't born in Rome but in Romania—in Bucharest
Christina Onassis wasn't born in Greece but in this U.S. metropolis
Composer Edward Elgar was born in this "saucy" English county in 1857
This Belgian seaport city was the birthplace of portrait artist Anthony van Dyck
G. Flaubert's birthplace in this city, where Joan of arc was burned at the stake, is now a museum
Though based in part on Norse legends, the operas were written in this language
The prologue to the ring cycle opens on the bed of this river where the maidens guard the gold
Name shared by Wagner's son & the hero of the Ring Cycle
In "Die Walkure" she disobeys her father & is put to sleep on a rock
This last piece in the tetralogy debuted August 17, 1876, the day after Part Three

rounds.category: IT'S OUR TURN TO SACK ROME!!!

clues.text:
390 B.C.:
These people usually associated with ancient France sack Rome

410 A.D.:
Under Alaric, these "Westerners" sack Rome

455 A.D.:
These people, whose name is now synonymous with pillage & destruction, sack Rome

1084 A.D.:
Having successfully invaded England 18 years before, they then sack Rome

1527 A.D.:
Spanish & German troops working for this "Empire" end the High Renaissance by sacking Rome
Fran Lebowitz jokingly said, "My favorite animal is" this, but she didn't specify porterhouse or T-bone
This breakfast goody has been described as "an unsweetened doughnut with rigor mortis"
Mark Twain said that cauliflower "is nothing but" this vegetable "with a college education"
This president said, "You can tell a lot about a fellow's character" by his way of eating jellybeans
Thackeray's "Ballad of" this dish calls it "a sort of soup or broth... or hotchpotch of all sorts of fishes"
This superhero was raised by his Aunt May
Aunt Chloe is the long-suffering wife of this Harriet Beecher Stowe character
In "Pride & Prejudice", this heroine tours Pemberley with Mrs. Gardiner, a favorite aunt
Ann Dowd won an Emmy for playing the tyrannical overseer Aunt Lydia on this dystopian favorite
Betsey Trotwood is great-aunt & guardian to this Dickens title character
Nietzsche named the wild, creative impulse for Dionysus & the orderly one for this sun god
Henri Bergson saw this not as a series of moments but as a flow he called duration
His "Two Treatises of Government", which influenced Jefferson, said man has a natural right to liberty
This man who died around 347 B.C. said we perceive examples of things, not their ideal forms
Hobbes followed this -ism, not meaning he was greedy but that he reduced every experience to a physical process
This ex-planet's average distance of 3.7 billion miles from Earth could pose commuting problems
You might want to wish upon Proxima this, a star only 4.2 light-years from our sun
Not many are looking to settle in Valles Marineris, canyons discovered on this planet by Mariner 9 in 1972
If you have your heart set on this 2-letter moon of Jupiter, pack a coat; temperatures get below -225 degrees
Want land? Buying on this moon of Saturn is a no-brainer; its 3,200-mile diameter is bigger than Mercury!
Thousands died in 1952 in a notorious smoggy event in this European capital
This molecule, O<sub>3</sub>, is a pollutant low in the atmosphere; in the stratosphere, it absorbs harmful radiation
Most air pollution comes from burning these alliterative combustibles that consist of organic remains
Dust pollution from this "depleted" metal used on armor-piercing weapons may cause cancer
PM is short for this, which can be composed of soot, smoke or dust in the air

rounds.text: Around 1930 a bank named for this NYC area known as a slum was the USA's largest savings bank by total deposits
